content.html:
Your product, service, or organisation almost certainly has a priority of constituencies, even if it‚Äôs not written down or otherwise formally-encoded. A famous example would be that expressed in the Web Platform Design Principles. It dictates how you decide between two competing needs, all other things being equal.

At Three Rings, for example, our priority of constituencies might1 look like this:

  1. The needs of volunteers are more important than
  2. The needs of voluntary organisations, which are more important than
  3. Continuation of the Three Rings service, which is more important than
  4. Adherance to technical standards and best practice, which is more important than
  5. Development of new features

These are all things we care about, but we‚Äôre talking about where we might choose to rank them, relative to one another.

The priorities of an organisation you‚Äôre involved with won‚Äôt be the same: perhaps it includes shareholders, regulatory compliance, different kinds of end-users, employees, profits, different measures of social good, or various measurable outputs. That‚Äôs fine: every system is different.

But what I‚Äôd challenge you to do is find ways to bisect your priorities. Invent scenarios that pit each constituency against itself another and discuss how they should be prioritised, all other things being equal.

Using the example above, I might ask ‚Äúwhich is more important?‚Äù in each category:

  1. The needs of the volunteers developing Three Rings, or the needs of the volunteers who use it?
  2. The needs of organisations that currently use the system, or the needs of organisations that are considering using it?
  3. Achieving a high level of uptime, or promptly installing system updates?
  4. Compliance with standards as-written, or maximum compatibility with devices as-used?
  5. Implementation of new features that are the most popular user requests, or those which provide the biggest impact-to-effort payoff?

The aim of the exercise isn‚Äôt to come up with a set of commandments for your company. If you come up with something you can codify, that‚Äôs great, but if you and your stakeholders just use it as an exercise in understanding the relative importance of different goals, that‚Äôs great too. Finding where people disagree is more-important than having a unifying creed2.

And of course this exercise applicable to more than just organisational priorities. Use it for projects or standards. Use it for systems where you‚Äôre the only participant, as a thought exercise. A priority of constituencies can be a beautiful thing, but you can understand it better if you‚Äôre willing to take it apart once in a while. Bisect your priorities, and see what you find.

Footnotes

1 Three Rings doesn‚Äôt have an explicit priority of constituencies: the example I give is based on my own interpretation, but I‚Äôm only a small part of the organisation.

2 Having a creed is awesome too, though, as I‚Äôve said before.

Your product, service, or organisation almost certainly has a priority of constituencies, even if it‚Äôs not written down or otherwise formally-encoded. A famous example would be that expressed in the Web Platform Design Principles. It dictates how you decide between two competing needs, all other things being equal.
At Three Rings, for example, our priority of constituencies might1 look like this:

The needs of volunteers are more important than
The needs of voluntary organisations, which are more important than
Continuation of the Three Rings service, which is more important than
Adherance to technical standards and best practice, which is more important than
Development of new features

These are all things we care about, but we‚Äôre talking about where we might choose to rank them, relative to one another.
 Semicircular illustration showing five facets of growing relative importance. From least to most, they are: new features, standards-compliance, service continuity, organisation needs, volunteer needs.  Semicircular illustration showing five facets of growing relative importance. From least to most, they are: new features, standards-compliance, service continuity, organisation needs, volunteer needs. The priorities and constituencies portrayed in this illustration are ficticious. Any resemblence to real priorities and constituencies, whether living or dead, is entirely coincidental.
The priorities of an organisation you‚Äôre involved with won‚Äôt be the same: perhaps it includes shareholders, regulatory compliance, different kinds of end-users, employees, profits, different measures of social good, or various measurable outputs. That‚Äôs fine: every system is different.
But what I‚Äôd challenge you to do is find ways to bisect your priorities. Invent scenarios that pit each constituency against itself another and discuss how they should be prioritised, all other things being equal.
Using the example above, I might ask ‚Äúwhich is more important?‚Äù in each category:

The needs of the volunteers developing Three Rings, or the needs of the volunteers who use it?
The needs of organisations that currently use the system, or the needs of organisations that are considering using it?
Achieving a high level of uptime, or promptly installing system updates?
Compliance with standards as-written, or maximum compatibility with devices as-used?
Implementation of new features that are the most popular user requests, or those which provide the biggest impact-to-effort payoff?

 Illustrated priority list from above, which each item split into two and re-named such that they are, from least to most important: popular features, impact features, compliance, usability, uptime, updates, future clients, current clients, other volunteers, our volunteers.  Illustrated priority list from above, which each item split into two and re-named such that they are, from least to most important: popular features, impact features, compliance, usability, uptime, updates, future clients, current clients, other volunteers, our volunteers. These might not be your answers to the same questions. They‚Äôre not even necessarily mine, and they‚Äôre even less-likely to be representative of Three Rings CIC. It‚Äôs just illustrative.
The aim of the exercise isn‚Äôt to come up with a set of commandments for your company. If you come up with something you can codify, that‚Äôs great, but if you and your stakeholders just use it as an exercise in understanding the relative importance of different goals, that‚Äôs great too. Finding where people disagree is more-important than having a unifying creed2.
And of course this exercise applicable to more than just organisational priorities. Use it for projects or standards. Use it for systems where you‚Äôre the only participant, as a thought exercise. A priority of constituencies can be a beautiful thing, but you can understand it better if you‚Äôre willing to take it apart once in a while. Bisect your priorities, and see what you find.
Footnotes1 Three Rings doesn‚Äôt have an explicit priority of constituencies: the example I give is based on my own interpretation, but I‚Äôm only a small part of the organisation.2 Having a creed is awesome too, though, as I‚Äôve said before.

Kids: We want porridge for breakfast.
Me: How do you want it?
Kids: Surprise us.
Presenting‚Ä¶ oatmeal, honey and sultanas with a toasted marshmallow.
 Two bowls of porridge with sultanas, each topped with a jumbo marshmallow (one pink, one white) being toasted by a blowtorch (mostly off-camera).  Two bowls of porridge with sultanas, each topped with a jumbo marshmallow (one pink, one white) being toasted by a blowtorch (mostly off-camera).

content.html:
Somebody shared with me a tweet about the tragedy of being a Gen X‚Äôer and having to buy all your music again and again as formats evolve. Somebody else shared with me Kyla La Grange‚Äòs cover of a particular song .Together‚Ä¶ these reminded me that I‚Äôve never told you the story of my first¬†MP3‚Ä¶1

In the Summer of 1995 I bought the CD single of the (still excellent!) Set You Free by N-Trance.2 I‚Äôd heard about this new-fangled ‚ÄúMP3‚Äù audio format, so soon afterwards I decided to rip a copy of the song to my PC.

I was using a 66MHz 486SX CPU, and without an embedded FPU I didn‚Äôt quite have the spare processing power to rip-and-encode in a single pass.3 So instead I first ripped to an uncompressed PCM .wav file and then performed the encoding: the former step was done almost in real-time (I listened to the track as it ripped!), about 7 minutes. The latter step took about 20 minutes.

So‚Ä¶ about half an hour in total, to rip a single song.

Creating a (what would now be considered an apalling) 32kHz mono-channel file, this meant that I briefly stored both a 27MB wave file and the final ~4MB MP3 file. 31MB might not sound huge, but I only had a total of 145MB of hard drive space at the time, so 31MB consumed over a fifth of my entire fixed storage! Even after deleting the intermediary wave file I was left with a single song consuming around 3% of my space, which is mind-boggling to think about in hindsight.

But it felt like magic. I called my friend Gary to tell him about it. ‚ÄúThis is going to be massive!‚Äù I said. At the time, I meant for techy people: I could imagine a future in which, with more hard drive space, I‚Äôd keep all my music this way‚Ä¶ or else bundle entire artists onto writable CDs in this new format, making albums obsolete. I never considered that over the coming decade or so the format would enter the public consciousness, let alone that it‚Äôd take off like it did.

The MP3 file I produced had a fault. Most of the way through the encoding process, I got bored and ran another program, and this must‚Äôve interfered with the stream because there was an audible ‚Äúblip‚Äù noise about 30 seconds from the end of the track. You‚Äôd have to be listening carefully to hear it, or else know what you were looking for, but it was there. I didn‚Äôt want to go through the whole process again, so I left it.

But that artefact uniquely identified that copy of what was, in the end, a popular song to have in your digital music collection. As the years went by and I traded MP3 files in bulk at LAN parties or on CD-Rs or, on at least one ocassion, on an Iomega Zip disk (remember those?), I‚Äôd ocassionally see N-Trance - (Only Love Can) Set You Free.mp34 being passed around and play it, to see if it was ‚Äúmy‚Äù copy.

Sometimes the ID3 tags had been changed because for example the previous owner had decided it deserved to be considered Genre: Dance instead of Genre: Trance5. But I could still identify that file because of the audio fingerprint, distinct to the first MP3 I ever created.

I still had that file when I went to university (where it occupied a smaller proportion of my hard drive space) and hearing that distinctive ‚Äúblip‚Äù would remind me about the ordeal that was involved in its creation. I don‚Äôt have it any more, but perhaps somebody else still does.

Footnotes

1 I might never have told this story on my blog, but eagle-eyed readers may remember that I‚Äôve certainly hinted at it before now.

2 Rewatching that music video, I‚Äôm struck by a recollection of how crazy popular crossfades were on 1990s dance music videos. More than just a transition, I‚Äôm pretty sure that most of the frames of that video are mid-crossfade: it feels like I‚Äôm watching Kelly Llorenna hanging out of a sunroof but I accidentally left one of my eyeballs in a smoky nightclub and can still see out of it as well.

3 I initially tried to convert directly from red book format to an MP3 file, but the encoding process was too slow and the CD drive‚Äôs buffer filled up and didn‚Äôt get drained by the processor, which was still presumably bogged down with framing or fourier-transforming earlier parts of the track. The CD drive reasonably assumed that it wasn‚Äôt actually being used and spun-down the drive motor, and this caused it to lose its place in the track, killing the whole process and leaving me with about a 40 second recording.

4 Yes, that filename isn‚Äôt quite the correct title. I was wrong.

5 No, it‚Äôs clearly trance. They were wrong.

Somebody shared with me a tweet about the tragedy of being a Gen X‚Äôer and having to buy all your music again and again as formats evolve. Somebody else shared with me Kyla La Grange‚Äòs cover of a particular song .Together‚Ä¶ these reminded me that I‚Äôve never told you the story of my first¬†MP3‚Ä¶1
 Screenshot of tweet by @bewgtweets posted Oct 17, 2021, reading: If you want to know why Gen X‚Äôers are always mad it‚Äôs because we had to replace our record collections with a tape collection that was then replaced with a cd collection that was then replaced with MP3‚Äôs and damn it how many time must I pay to listen to grunge  Screenshot of tweet by @bewgtweets posted Oct 17, 2021, reading: If you want to know why Gen X‚Äôers are always mad it‚Äôs because we had to replace our record collections with a tape collection that was then replaced with a cd collection that was then replaced with MP3‚Äôs and damn it how many time must I pay to listen to grunge I didn‚Äôt/don‚Äôt own much vinyl ‚Äì perhaps mostly because I had a tape deck in my bedroom years before a record player ‚Äì but I‚Äôve felt this pain. And don‚Äôt get me started on the videogames I‚Äôve paid for multiple times.
In the Summer of 1995 I bought the CD single of the (still excellent!) Set You Free by N-Trance.2 I‚Äôd heard about this new-fangled ‚ÄúMP3‚Äù audio format, so soon afterwards I decided to rip a copy of the song to my PC.

The latter step took about 20 minutes.
So‚Ä¶ about half an hour in total, to rip a single song.
 Dan, as a teenager, sits at a desk with his hand to his chin. In the foreground, a beiege two-button wired ball-type computer mouse rests on the corner of the desk. Dan is wearing a black t-shirt with a red devil face printed onto it.  Dan, as a teenager, sits at a desk with his hand to his chin. In the foreground, a beiege two-button wired ball-type computer mouse rests on the corner of the desk. Dan is wearing a black t-shirt with a red devil face printed onto it. Progress bar, you say? I‚Äôll just sit here and wait then, I guess. Actual contemporary-ish photo.
Creating a (what would now be considered an apalling) 32kHz mono-channel file, this meant that I briefly stored both a 27MB wave file and the final ~4MB MP3 file. 31MB might not sound huge, but I only had a total of 145MB of hard drive space at the time, so 31MB consumed over a fifth of my entire fixed storage! Even after deleting the intermediary wave file I was left with a single song consuming around 3% of my space, which is mind-boggling to think about in hindsight.
But it felt like magic. I called my friend Gary to tell him about it. ‚ÄúThis is going to be massive!‚Äù I said. At the time, I meant for techy people: I could imagine a future in which, with more hard drive space, I‚Äôd keep all my music this way‚Ä¶ or else bundle entire artists onto writable CDs in this new format, making albums obsolete. I never considered that over the coming decade or so the format would enter the public consciousness, let alone that it‚Äôd take off like it did.
 A young man in jeans and a blue coat stands on the patio in the back garden of a terraced house, dropping a half-brick onto the floor. In the background, an unused rabbit hutch and a dustbin can be seen. The photo is clearly taken using a flash, at night.  A young man in jeans and a blue coat stands on the patio in the back garden of a terraced house, dropping a half-brick onto the floor. In the background, an unused rabbit hutch and a dustbin can be seen. The photo is clearly taken using a flash, at night. If you‚Äôre thinking of Gary and I as the kind of reprobates who helped bring on the golden age of music piracy‚Ä¶ I‚Äôd like to distract you with a bigger show of yobbish behaviour in the form of this photo from the day we played at dropping half-bricks onto starter pistol ammunition.
The MP3 file I produced had a fault. Most of the way through the encoding process, I got bored and ran another program, and this must‚Äôve interfered with the stream because there was an audible ‚Äúblip‚Äù noise about 30 seconds from the end of the track. You‚Äôd have to be listening carefully to hear it, or else know what you were looking for, but it was there. I didn‚Äôt want to go through the whole process again, so I left it.
But that artefact uniquely identified that copy of what was, in the end, a popular song to have in your digital music collection. As the years went by and I traded MP3 files in bulk at LAN parties or on CD-Rs or, on at least one ocassion, on an Iomega Zip disk (remember those?), I‚Äôd ocassionally see N-Trance - (Only Love Can) Set You Free.mp34 being passed around and play it, to see if it was ‚Äúmy‚Äù copy.
Sometimes the ID3 tags had been changed because for example the previous owner had decided it deserved to be considered Genre: Dance instead of Genre: Trance5. But I could still identify that file because of the audio fingerprint, distinct to the first MP3 I ever created.
I still had that file when I went to university (where it occupied a smaller proportion of my hard drive space) and hearing that distinctive ‚Äúblip‚Äù would remind me about the ordeal that was involved in its creation. I don‚Äôt have it any more, but perhaps somebody else still does.
Footnotes1 I might never have told this story on my blog, but eagle-eyed readers may remember that I‚Äôve certainly hinted at it before now.2 Rewatching that music video, I‚Äôm struck by a recollection of how crazy popular crossfades were on 1990s dance music videos. More than just a transition, I‚Äôm pretty sure that most of the frames of that video are mid-crossfade: it feels like I‚Äôm watching Kelly Llorenna hanging out of a sunroof but I accidentally left one of my eyeballs in a smoky nightclub and can still see out of it as well.3 I initially tried to convert directly from red book format to an MP3 file, but the encoding process was too slow and the CD drive‚Äôs buffer filled up and didn‚Äôt get drained by the processor, which was still presumably bogged down with framing or fourier-transforming earlier parts of the track. The CD drive reasonably assumed that it wasn‚Äôt actually being used and spun-down the drive motor, and this caused it to lose its place in the track, killing the whole process and leaving me with about a 40 second recording.4 Yes, that filename isn‚Äôt quite the correct title. I was wrong.5 No, it‚Äôs clearly trance. They were wrong.

content.html:
I‚Äôve been spending a while running on reduced brain capacity lately so, to ease myself back into thinking like a programmer, I upgraded my preferred feed reader FreshRSS to version 1.20.0 ‚Äì which was released a couple of weeks ago ‚Äì and tried out what I believe is its killer new feature: HTML + XPath scraping.

I‚Äôve been using RSS1 for about 20 years and I love it. It feels great to be able to curate my updates based on ‚Äúwhat I care about‚Äù, and not on ‚Äúwhat some social network thinks I should care about‚Äù, to keep things to read later, to prioritise effectively based on my own categorisation, to consume content offline and have my to-read list synchronise later, etc.

RSS never went away, of course (what do you think a podcast is?), but it got steamrollered out of the public eye by big companies who make their money out of keeping your eyes on their platforms and off the open Web. But it feels like it‚Äôs slowly coming back: even Substack ‚Äì whose entire thing is that an email client is more-convenient than a feed reader for most people ‚Äì launched an RSS reader this week!

I love RSS so much that I routinely retrofit other people‚Äôs websites with feeds just so I can subscribe to them: I even published the tool I use to do so! Whether filtering sports headlines out of BBC News, turning retro webcomics into ‚Äúreading lists‚Äù so I can track my progress, or just working around sites that really should have feeds but refuse to, I just love sidestepping these ‚Äúmissing feeds‚Äù. My friend Beverley has a blog without any kind of feed, so I added one so I could subscribe to it. Magic.

But with FreshRSS 1.20.0, I no longer have to maintain my own tool to get this brilliant functionality, and I‚Äôm overjoyed. Let‚Äôs look at how it works by re-subscribing to Beverley‚Äôs blog but without a middleware tool.

In the latest version of FreshRSS, when you add a new feed to your reader, a new section ‚ÄúType of feed source‚Äù is available. Unfold it, and you can change from the default (‚ÄúRSS / Atom‚Äù) to the new option ‚ÄúHTML + XPath (Web scraping)‚Äù. Put a human-readable page address rather than a feed address into the ‚ÄúFeed URL‚Äù field and fill these fields to tell FreshRSS how to parse the page to get the content you want. Note that it doesn‚Äôt matter if the web page isn‚Äôt valid XML (e.g. missing closing tags) because it‚Äôs going to get run through PHP‚Äôs DOMDocument anyway which will ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù for some really sloppy code if needed.

You‚Äôll need to use XPath to express how to find a ‚Äúfeed item‚Äù on the page. Here‚Äôs the rules I used for https://webdevbev.co.uk/blog.html (many of these fields were optional ‚Äì I didn‚Äôt have to do this much work):

  • Feed title: //h1
    I override this anyway in FreshRSS, so I could just have used the a string, but I wanted the XPath practice. There‚Äôs only one <h1> on the page, and it can be considered the ‚Äútitle‚Äù of the feed.
  • Finding items: //li[@class="blog__post-preview"]
    Each ‚Äúpost‚Äù on the page is an <li class="blog__post-preview">.
  • Item titles: descendant::h2
    Each post has a <h2> which is the post title. The descendant:: selector scopes the search to each post as found above.
  • Item content: descendant::p[3]
    Beverley‚Äôs static site generator template puts the post summary in the third paragraph of the <li>, which we can select like this.
  • Item link: descendant::h2/a/@href
    This expects a URL, so we need the /@href to make sure we get the value of the <h2><a href="...">, rather than its contents.
  • Item thumbnail: descendant::img[@class="blog__image--preview"]/@src
    Again, this expects a URL, which we get from the <img src="...">.
  • Item author: "Beverley Newing"
    Beverley‚Äôs blog doesn‚Äôt host any guest posts, so I just use a string literal here.
  • Item date: substring-after(descendant::p[@class="blog__date-posted"], "Date posted: ")
    This is the only complicated one: the published dates on Beverley‚Äôs blog aren‚Äôt explicitly marked-up, but part of a string that begins with the words ‚ÄúDate posted: ‚Äú, so I use XPath‚Äôs substring-after function to strtip this. The result gets passed to PHP‚Äôs strtotime(), which is pretty tolerant of different date formats (although not of the words ‚ÄúDate posted:‚Äù it turns out!).

I hope that this is just the beginning for this new killer feature in FreshRSS: there‚Äôs so much more it can be and do. But for now, I‚Äôm still mighty impressed that I can begin to phase-out my use of my relatively resource-intensive feed-building middleware and use my feed reader to do more and more of the heavy lifting for which I love it so much.

I also love that this functionally adds h-feed support in by the back door. I‚Äôd still prefer there to be a ‚Äúh-feed‚Äù option in the ‚ÄúType of feed source‚Äù drop-down, but at least I can add such support manually, now!

Footnotes

1 When I say RSS, I mean feed. Most of the feeds I subscribe to are RSS feeds, but some are Atom feeds, h-feed, etc. But I can‚Äôt get over the old-fashioned name, and I don‚Äôt care to try.

Screenshot showing FetchRSS being used to graphically create a feed from Beverley's blog. This post is about to get pretty technical. If you don‚Äôt want to learn some XPath but just want to make a feed out of a web page, use a graphical tool like FetchRSS. Unfold it, and you can change from the default (‚ÄúRSS / Atom‚Äù) to the new option ‚ÄúHTML + XPath (Web scraping)‚Äù. Browser debugger running document.evaluate('//li[@class="blog__post-preview"]', document).iterateNext() on Beverley's weblog and getting the first blog entry. Browser debugger running document.evaluate('//li[@class="blog__post-preview"]', document).iterateNext() on Beverley's weblog and getting the first blog entry. You can use your browser‚Äôs debugger to help check your XPath rules: here I‚Äôve run¬† document.evaluate('//li[@class="blog__post-preview"]', document).iterateNext() and got back the first blog post on the page, so I know I‚Äôm on the right track.You‚Äôll need to use XPath to express how to find a ‚Äúfeed item‚Äù on the page.     which is the post title. The descendant:: selector scopes the search to each post as found above. Item content: descendant::p[3] Beverley‚Äôs static site generator template puts the post summary in the third paragraph of the
  • , which we can select like this. Item link: descendant::h2/a/@href This expects a URL, so we need the /@href to make sure we get the value of the

    , rather than its contents. Item thumbnail: descendant::img[@class="blog__image--preview"]/@src Again, this expects a URL, which we get from the . Item author: "Beverley Newing" Beverley‚Äôs blog doesn‚Äôt host any guest posts, so I just use a string literal here. Item date: substring-after(descendant::p[@class="blog__date-posted"], "Date posted: ") This is the only complicated one: the published dates on Beverley‚Äôs blog aren‚Äôt explicitly marked-up, but part of a string that begins with the words ‚ÄúDate posted: ‚Äú, so I use XPath‚Äôs substring-after function to strtip this. The result gets passed to PHP‚Äôs strtotime(), which is pretty tolerant of different date formats (although not of the words ‚ÄúDate posted:‚Äù it turns out!). Screenshot: Adding a "HTML + XPath (Web scraping)" feed via FreshRSS. Screenshot: Adding a "HTML + XPath (Web scraping)" feed via FreshRSS. I‚Äôd love one day for FreshRSS to provide some kind of ‚Äúpreview‚Äù feature here so you can see what you‚Äôll expect to get back, as you work. That, and support for different input types (JSON, perhaps?), perhaps other selectors (I find CSS-style selectors much simpler than XPath), and maybe even an option to execute Javascript on the page before scraping (I use this in my own toolchain, but that‚Äôs just because I want to have my cake and eat it too). But this is still all pretty awesome. I hope that this is just the beginning for this new killer feature in FreshRSS: there‚Äôs so much more it can be and do. But for now, I‚Äôm still mighty impressed that I can begin to phase-out my use of my relatively resource-intensive feed-building middleware and use my feed reader to do more and more of the heavy lifting for which I love it so much. I also love that this functionally adds h-feed support in by the back door. I‚Äôd still prefer there to be a ‚Äúh-feed‚Äù option in the ‚ÄúType of feed source‚Äù drop-down, but at least I can add such support manually, now! Beverley's blog post "Setting up an Accessibility Book Club" in FreshRSS. Beverley's blog post "Setting up an Accessibility Book Club" in FreshRSS. The finished result: Bev‚Äôs blog posts appear directly in my feed reader, even though they don‚Äôt have a feed, and now without going through the middleware I‚Äôd set up for that purpose. Footnotes1 When I say RSS, I mean feed. Most of the feeds I subscribe to are RSS feeds, but some are Atom feeds, h-feed, etc. But I can‚Äôt get over the old-fashioned name, and I don‚Äôt care to try.

content.html: Was a 10th century speaker of Old Saxon a ‚ÄúSaxophone‚Äù? ü§î
content.value: Was a 10th century speaker of Old Saxon a ‚ÄúSaxophone‚Äù? ü§î

name: All the game descriptions from the sale

content.html:
You‚Äôve got 37 unpaid parking tickets. You just got pulled over for speeding. In your defense, you were texting your sister about how drunk you are. Plus there‚Äôs all that blood on your windshield. Obviously you know it‚Äôs deer blood, but the police officers walking toward your vehicle don‚Äôt. Still, in the time it takes them to figure that out, maybe you‚Äôll sober up. Or escape on foot! Either way, it‚Äôll probably be fine.

User Tags: Poor Choices / Story Rich / Multiple Endings / Parkour

Collect dead seagulls and build a zoo to house them all. Beautify the zoo with artistic flair and deodorizing sprays. Design creative group promotions to stir up interest! Is that a customer? You‚Äôd better hope it‚Äôs not the owner of the live seagull zoo down the street, because he‚Äôs probably got some questions.

User Tags: Hard Work / Supply / Demand / Diseases & Parasites

‚Ä¶

Claire Hummel

Claire Hummel produced fake video game art for the Steam Summer Sale, which was already excellent, but when @g-a-y-g-o-y-l-e reblogged, asking for more context, Claire delivered and then some. Every single one of these ‚Äúgame descriptions‚Äù is a special kind of comedy gold‚Ä¶ and yet somehow believable from the store that sells us Dream Daddy, IKEA VR Pancake Kitchen, Organ Trail, Oh‚Ä¶ Sir!! The Insult Simulator, and Goat Simulator (all of which I own copies of). Go read the full list.

content.html:
I managed to dodge infection for 922 days of the Covid pandemic1, but it caught up with me eventually.

Frankly, it‚Äôs surprising that it took this long. We‚Äôve always been careful, in accordance with guidance at any given time, nd we all got our jabs and boosters as soon as we were able‚Ä¶ but conversely: we‚Äôve got school-age children who naturally seem to be the biggest disease vectors imaginable. Our youngest, in fact, already had Covid, but the rest of us managed to dodge it perhaps thanks to all these precautions.

Luckily I‚Äôm not suffering too badly, probably thanks to the immunisation. It‚Äôs still not great, but I dread to think how it might have been without the benefit of the jab! A minor fever came and went, and then it‚Äôs just been a few days of coughing, exhaustion, and‚Ä¶ the most-incredible level of brain-fog.

I‚Äôve taken the week off work to recover, which was a wise choice. As well as getting rest, it‚Äôs meant that I‚Äôve managed to avoid writing production code with my addled brain! Instead, I‚Äôve spent a lot of time chilling in bed and watching all of the films that I‚Äôd been meaning to! This week, I‚Äôve watched:

  • Peggy Sue Got Married (y‚Äôknow, that other mid-1980s movie about time travel and being a teenager in the 1950s). It was okay; some bits of the direction were spectacular for its age, like the ‚Äúthrough the mirror‚Äù filming.
  • Fall. I enjoyed this more than I expected to. It‚Äôs not great, but while I spent most of the time complaining about the lack of believability in the setting and the characters‚Äô reactions, the acting was good and the tension ‚Äúworked‚Äù: it was ocassionally pretty vertigo-inducing, and that‚Äôs not just because I‚Äôve been having some Covid-related dizziness!
  • RRR. Oh my god this Tollywood action spectacle was an adventure. At one point it‚Äôs a bromantic buddy comedy, then later there‚Äôs a dance-off, then for a while there‚Äôs a wonderful ‚Äúeven language can‚Äôt divide us‚Äù romance, but then later a man picks up a motorcycle with one hand and uses it to beat up an entire army, and somehow it all feels like it belongs together. The symbolism‚Äôs so thick you can spread it (tl;dr: colonialism bad), but it‚Äôs still a riot of a film.
  • Cyrano, which I feel was under-rated but that could just be that I have a soft spot for the story‚Ä¶ and a love of musical theatre.
  • Also, at times when I didn‚Äôt think my brain had the focus for something new, I re-watched Dude, Where‚Äôs My Car? because I figured a stoner comedy that re-replains the plot every 20 minutes or so was about as good as I could expect my brain to handle at the time, and Everything Everywhere All At Once which I‚Äôve now seen three times and loved every single one: it‚Äôs one of my favourite films.

Anyway: hopefully next week I‚Äôll be feeling more normal and my poor Covid-struck brain can be trusted with code again. Until then: time to try to rest some more.

Footnotes

1 Based on the World Health Organisation‚Äôs declaration of the outbreak being a pandemic on 11 March 2020 and my positive test on 19 September 2022, I stayed uninfected for two years, six months, one week, and one day. But who‚Äôs counting?
content.value:
I managed to dodge infection for 922 days of the Covid pandemic1, but it caught up with me eventually.
 Lateral flow test, with "DAN" written on it, showing a solid control line and a very clear solid test line: a clear positive result.  Lateral flow test, with "DAN" written on it, showing a solid control line and a very clear solid test line: a clear positive result. Well, shit.
Frankly, it‚Äôs surprising that it took this long. We‚Äôve always been careful, in accordance with guidance at any given time, nd we all got our jabs and boosters as soon as we were able‚Ä¶ but conversely: we‚Äôve got school-age children who naturally seem to be the biggest disease vectors imaginable. Our youngest, in fact, already had Covid, but the rest of us managed to dodge it perhaps thanks to all these precautions.
 Vials of Covid vaccine scattered across a red background. Photo courtesy Maksim Goncharenok.  Vials of Covid vaccine scattered across a red background. Photo courtesy Maksim Goncharenok. The vaccine provide protection, but it‚Äôs not a magical force-field.
Luckily I‚Äôm not suffering too badly, probably thanks to the immunisation. It‚Äôs still not great, but I dread to think how it might have been without the benefit of the jab! A minor fever came and went, and then it‚Äôs just been a few days of coughing, exhaustion, and‚Ä¶ the most-incredible level of brain-fog.
 Dan with the dog, in the garden.  Dan with the dog, in the garden. Today, for example, I completey blanked the word ‚Äútoilet‚Äù and struggled for some time to express to the dog why I‚Äôd brought her into the garden, while she stared at me expectantly.
I‚Äôve taken the week off work to recover, which was a wise choice. As well as getting rest, it‚Äôs meant that I‚Äôve managed to avoid writing production code with my addled brain! Instead, I‚Äôve spent a lot of time chilling in bed and watching all of the films that I‚Äôd been meaning to! This week, I‚Äôve watched:

Peggy Sue Got Married (y‚Äôknow, that other mid-1980s movie about time travel and being a teenager in the 1950s). It was okay; some bits of the direction were spectacular for its age, like the ‚Äúthrough the mirror‚Äù filming.
Fall. I enjoyed this more than I expected to. It‚Äôs not great, but while I spent most of the time complaining about the lack of believability in the setting and the characters‚Äô reactions, the acting was good and the tension ‚Äúworked‚Äù: it was ocassionally pretty vertigo-inducing, and that‚Äôs not just because I‚Äôve been having some Covid-related dizziness!
RRR. Oh my god this Tollywood action spectacle was an adventure. At one point it‚Äôs a bromantic buddy comedy, then later there‚Äôs a dance-off, then for a while there‚Äôs a wonderful ‚Äúeven language can‚Äôt divide us‚Äù romance, but then later a man picks up a motorcycle with one hand and uses it to beat up an entire army, and somehow it all feels like it belongs together. The symbolism‚Äôs so thick you can spread it (tl;dr: colonialism bad), but it‚Äôs still a riot of a film.
Cyrano, which I feel was under-rated but that could just be that I have a soft spot for the story‚Ä¶ and a love of musical theatre.
Also, at times when I didn‚Äôt think my brain had the focus for something new, I re-watched Dude, Where‚Äôs My Car? because I figured a stoner comedy that re-replains the plot every 20 minutes or so was about as good as I could expect my brain to handle at the time, and Everything Everywhere All At Once which I‚Äôve now seen three times and loved every single one: it‚Äôs one of my favourite films.

 Dan lying in bed, giving a weak "thumbs up".  Dan lying in bed, giving a weak "thumbs up". See, I‚Äôm fine! (Feel like I‚Äôve spent a lot of time lying here, this week.)
Anyway: hopefully next week I‚Äôll be feeling more normal and my poor Covid-struck brain can be trusted with code again. Until then: time to try to rest some more.
Footnotes1 Based on the World Health Organisation‚Äôs declaration of the outbreak being a pandemic on 11 March 2020 and my positive test on 19 September 2022, I stayed uninfected for two years, six months, one week, and one day. But who‚Äôs counting?

      more of Dan's cache logs.

content.html:
Could have been expected to get the FTF for this one, given that it‚Äôs (a) literally 20 seconds walk from my front door and (b) the CO had indicated that one would be hidden around here, but unfortunately I contracted covid last weekend and any walk longer tab my garden was quickly leaving me exhausted. This evening I felt a little better and so the geohound and I (pictured) braved a couple of minutes in the rain to come and sign the logbook.

Note to future cachers planning to park and grab: the ‚Äúlayby‚Äù indicated is a working bus stop, albeit with an infrequent (every 2 hours, weekday daytimes) schedule, so remember to be a polite cacher and try not to park in it at times that it‚Äôll be needed by the minibus!

I might need to find a new home for my replacement to GC90RH3, whose bridge hiding place is only 100m or so (less than the requisite 0.1 miles!) from this new cache! Ah well, that‚Äôll teach me to be a slow CO!

TFTC, and for getting me out of the house for a walk for the first time since I got sick almost a week ago.
